questions.text: Which among the following is not a clinical finding of fibrocystic disease of the breast?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Fibrocystic disease of the breast is a benign condition, most common in the 4th-5th decades, and usually subsides after menopause.
  • It represents an exaggerated stromal and epithelial response to circulating hormones and local growth factors.
  • Typical features include:
    • Premenstrual cyclic breast pain (Option A ruled out)
    • Breast tenderness (Option B ruled out)
    • Palpable nodularity (lumpy-bumpy feel) (Option D ruled out)
  • Nipple discharge is not a typical feature.
  • Investigation of Choice:
    • Mammography is the investigation of choice in women >35 years.
    • Ultrasound is preferred in younger women (<35 years) because of dense breast tissue.
    • FNAC / Core needle biopsy may be required to exclude malignancy if suspicious.
  • Management
  • General: Reassurance, as it is benign and often regresses after menopause.
  • Medical:
    • Analgesics / NSAIDs for pain
    • Hormonal therapy in severe cases (danazol, tamoxifen, oral contraceptives - rarely used due to side effects)
  • Surgical: Rarely indicated; excision is considered only for persistent or suspicious lesions.

questions.text: Which among the following is not an indication of surgery in a male gynaecomastia patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Gynecomastia is hypertrophy of breast tissue in men.

Common causes include:

  • Physiological - neonatal period, puberty and senescence
  • Drugs- digoxin, thiazides, estrogens, phenothiazines, theophylline, cannabis
  • May be a systemic manifestationof hepatic cirrhosis, renal failure, or malnutrition

Pubertal hypertrophy is generally treated by observation without surgery.

Indications for surgical excision include:

  • Unilateral gynecomastia (Option A ruled out)
  • Failure to regress (Option B ruled out)
  • Cosmetically unacceptable (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: Estrogen excess is the cause of gynecomastia in all of these conditions except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In Klinefelter syndrome, there is an androgen deficiency state leading to gynecomastia.

Gynecomastia generally does not predispose the male breast to cancer. However, there is an increased risk of breast cancer in Klinefelter syndrome.

Pathophysiologic Mechanisms of Gynecomastia

questions.solution:

questions.text: Which of the following is not a clinical feature of a staphylococcal breast abscess?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Staphylococcal breast abscess typically presents with point tenderness, erythema, and local hyperthermia.
  • Nipple discharge is not a characteristic feature of a staphylococcal breast abscess.

Treatment:

  • Initial management includes analgesics, antibiotics, and repeated aspiration of the abscess.
  • Incision and drainage (I&D) is indicated when:
    • The abscess does not resolve with repeated aspiration and antibiotics.
    • There is thinning or necrosis of the overlying skin.

choices.text: Also known as recurrent periductal mastitis
Condition of recurrent retromammary infections and abscess
Smoking is being implicated as the risk factor
Treated by antibiotics and incision and drainage

questions.text: Which among the following conditions is not true about Zuska's disease?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

It is a chronic condition characterised by recurrent retroareolar infections and abscesses.

choices.text: Thrombophlebeitis of the superficial veins of the breast

questions.text: Which among the following statements is false for Mondor's disease?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Mondor's disease rarely presents bilaterally, and most affected women have no evidence of thrombophlebitis elsewhere in the body.

The following features are observed in Mondor's Disease:

  • There is thrombophlebitis of the superficial veinsof the anterior chest wall and breast. (Option B ruled out )
  • The patient presents with pain and a tender, firm cord in the region of the involved vein.
  • This benign, self-limited(usually resolves within 4 to 6 weeks) disorder is not indicative of cancer. (Option D ruled out )
  • Rarely, the presentation is bilateral, and most women have no evidence of thrombophlebitis in other anatomic sites.
  • When the diagnosis is uncertain or when a mass is present near the tender cord, biopsy is indicated.
  • Treatment - Anti-inflammatory medications and warm compresses. (Option C ruled out )
  • When symptoms persist or are refractory to therapy, excision of the involved vein segment may be considered.

questions.text: Which among the following is the most common cause of spontaneous nipple discharge from a single duct of the breast?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Intraductal papilloma is the most common cause (60-80%) of spontaneous bloody nipple discharge from a single duct. It usually arises in the large subareolar ducts beneath the nipple. The discharge is often bloody or serosanguinous and typically not associated with a palpable mass.

Investigations:

  • Triple assessment: clinical breast exam, targeted mammography (including magnification views of the retroareolar region) and breast ultrasound to look for an intraductal mass/cystic dilated duct.
  • Duct excision/ductoscopy/galactography (if available) to visualise the duct and localise the lesion.
  • Core biopsy or excisional biopsy (microdochectomy) of the involved duct for histopathology to confirm papilloma and exclude atypia or carcinoma.
  • If discharge is not bloody and endocrine causes are suspected, check serum prolactin and thyroid function.

Management:

  • Surgical excision (microdochectomy/major duct excision) of the affected duct is the treatment of choice for symptomatic single-duct papilloma (both diagnostic and curative) because it removes the source of bleeding and provides tissue for histology.
  • If histology shows atypia or malignancy, manage according to oncologic protocols (wider excision, multidisciplinary discussion).
  • Asymptomatic small papillomas found incidentally may be followed with imaging if biopsy proves benign and the patient prefers surveillance.

Explanation fo other options:

Duct ectasia (Option A): Accounts for ~20% of cases. Causes are thick, sticky, greenish or brownish discharge. It usually involves multiple ducts.

Galactorrhea (Option C): Refers to bilateral milky discharge, not spontaneous bloody discharge. Often related to hormonal causes (e.g., hyperprolactinemia, hypothyroidism, drugs).

Prolactinoma (Option D): A pituitary adenoma causing galactorrhea and menstrual irregularities. Produces bilateral milky discharge, not unilateral single-duct discharge.

questions.text: Which of the following figures indicates Paget's disease of the nipple?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Figure B shows Paget's disease of the nipple.

  • It is a superficial manifestation of an underlying breast carcinoma.
  • Presents as an eczema-likecondition of the nipple and areola, which persists despite local treatment.
  • Malignant ductal cells invade the epidermis without traversing the basement membrane of the subareolar duct or epidermis.
  • The nipple is eroded slowly, which may progress to ulceration.
  • Often mistaken for eczema. A biopsywill confirm the diagnosis.

Explanation for other options:

(Option A) Nipple discharge - Discharge from multiple ducts or bilateral discharge is a common finding in healthy breasts. In the case shown, the discharge is from a single duct orifice and may signify underlying disease in the discharging duct.

(Option C)Skin dimpling - Traction on Cooper ligaments (by a tumour) distorts the surface of the breast and produces a dimple best seen during abduction of the arms upward.

(Option D): Peau d'orange (skin of the orange) - This is seen in breast carcinoma when there is infiltration of the dermal lymphatics by malignant cells.

questions.text:
Match the Breast Condition with the Characteristic Nipple Discharge
Column A: Condition
A) Duct papilloma
B) Duct ectasia
C) Fibrocystic disease
D) Intraductal carcinoma
Column B: Nipple Discharge
1. Greenish
2. Serosanguinous/bloody
3. Clear/straw-colored
4. Bloody
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Duct ectasia is associated with a green or black secretion.

Nipple Discharge and Principal Causes

questions.text: Which among the following findings is seen in duct ectasia of the breast?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Duct Ectasia / Periductal Mastitis

Duct ectasia is a dilatation of the breast ducts, often associated with periductal inflammation.
The condition is more common in smokers.

Common symptoms include:

  • Nipple discharge (of any colour)
  • Subareolar mass
  • Abscess
  • Mammary duct fistula
  • Nipple retraction

Pathogenesis:
Initially, there is dilatation of one or more of the larger lactiferous ducts, which become filled with stagnant black or green secretions. These may eventually discharge from the nipple.
The retained secretions provoke an irritant inflammatory reaction in the surrounding tissue, leading to periductal mastitis, and in some cases, abscess or fistula formation.

In chronic cases, a firm, indurated mass may develop beneath the areola, sometimes mimicking carcinoma.
Over time, fibrosis can occur, resulting in slit-like nipple retraction.

questions.text: Which among the following is not included in the pathological change in aberrations of normal development and involution of the breast?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Nipple eversion is a part of the normal development of the breast.

Explanation of other Options:

Cyst formation (Option A): Cysts are almost inevitable and can vary greatly in size.

Fibrosis (Option B): Fat and elastic tissue disappear and are replaced by dense, white fibrous trabeculae. The interstitial tissue is often infiltrated with chronic inflammatory cells.

Papillomatosis (Option D): In some cases, epithelial hyperplasia is so extensive that it leads to papillomatous overgrowth within the ducts.

questions.text: Which among the following medications is not used in the treatment of breast pain?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Caffeine is not used in the treatment of breast pain. In fact, caffeine has been implicated as a potential aggravating factor in cyclic mastalgia. Avoiding caffeine may sometimes help reduce symptoms, but it is not a therapeutic agent.

Management of Breast Pain

questions.text: What is the usual age of occurrence of fibroadenoma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Fibroadenoma is a common benign breast tumour composed of both stromal (connective tissue) and epithelial (glandular) components. It is typically well-circumscribed, mobile, and painless.

Epidemiology:

  • Most common in young women aged 15-25 years, coinciding with peak hormonal activity.
  • Rarely occurs in prepubertal girls or postmenopausal women.
  • Represents ~50% of breast lumps in women under 25.

Pathophysiology:

  • Arises from hyperplasia of a single terminal duct-lobular unit.
  • Growth is hormone-sensitive, often influenced by estrogen, which explains enlargement during pregnancy or menstrual cycles.

Clinical Features:

  • Presentation: Painless, firm, rubbery, mobile mass with smooth borders.
  • Size: Usually 1 3 cm; can occasionally grow larger.
  • Location: Typically upper outer quadrant of the breast.
  • Can be solitary or multiple.
  • Rarely may be a giant fibroadenoma (>5 cm), especially in adolescents.

Investigations:

  • Ultrasound (USG) of the breast:
    • Well-defined, hypoechoic, homogeneous mass.
    • Wider-than-tall orientation ("parallel to skin"), suggesting a benign nature.
  • Mammography:
    • Usually shows a round or oval mass with smooth margins.
    • Limited utility in young women due to dense breast tissue.
  • Core needle biopsy / Fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC):
    • Confirms diagnosis if imaging is inconclusive or atypical features are present.

Management:

Conservative / Observation:

  • Indicated for typical fibroadenomas in women <25 years, especially if <2-3 cm and asymptomatic.
  • Periodic clinical and imaging follow-up is recommended.

Surgical / Interventional Management:

  • Excision indicated if:
    • The lump is very large or rapidly growing.
    • Patient requests removal for cosmetic reasons.
    • Atypical or suspicious cytology is present.
  • Alternatives to surgery:
    • Cryoablation: Freezing of the lesion under imaging guidance.
    • High-frequency ultrasound therapy: Heat-based ablation.
    • Large-core vacuum-assisted biopsy removal: Minimally invasive excision.

Histopathology:

  • Well-circumscribed lesion with a fibrous capsule.
  • Composed of proliferating stromal tissue and epithelial ducts.
  • No malignant potential, but complex fibroadenomas may slightly increase long-term breast cancer risk.

Differential Diagnosis:

  • Phyllodes tumour (can be benign or malignant; usually larger, faster-growing).
  • Cysts (tender, fluctuant, often hormonal).
  • Breast carcinoma (rare in this age group, irregular and fixed).

Prognosis:

  • Excellent; fibroadenomas are benign, rarely recur after excision.
  • Hormonal influences may cause growth or regression over time.

Key takeaway:

questions.text: What is the typical diameter of a giant fibroadenoma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A giant fibroadenoma is defined as a fibroadenoma measuring more than 5 cm in diameter and often demonstrates rapid growth.

  • It may occasionally occur during puberty (juvenile fibroadenoma).
  • Clinical features are otherwise similar to a typical fibroadenoma.
  • Surgical management is by enucleation through a submammary incision.
  • More common in Afro-Caribbean women.

questions.text: Serocystic disease of Brodie is another name for which condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Phyllodes tumour, also historically called Serocystic disease of Brodie or Cystosarcoma phyllodes, is a rare fibroepithelial breast tumour.

Epidemiology:

  • Usually occurs in women over 40 years, but it can also appear in younger women.

Clinical Features:

  • Often presents as a large, sometimes massive, breast mass.
  • The surface may be unevenly bosselated.
  • Occasional ulceration of the overlying skin can occur due to pressure necrosis.
  • The tumour is mobile over the chest wall.
  • Rarely, it may show sarcomatous transformation and metastasize via the bloodstream.

Investigations:

  • Ultrasound (USG): Heterogeneous, solid-cystic mass with well-defined margins.
  • Mammography: Large, lobulated mass; may show cystic areas.
  • Core needle biopsy / FNAC: Confirms fibroepithelial nature; helps differentiate benign vs malignant.
  • MRI: Useful in large or recurrent tumours to assess the extent.

Management:

  • Benign phyllodes: Wide local excision with clear margins (enucleation may be considered in young women).
  • Massive, recurrent, or malignant phyllodes: Mastectomy may be required.
  • Follow-up: Regular imaging to monitor for recurrence.

Explanation for other options:

  • Fibroadenoma (Option A): A firm, smooth, painless, benign breast lump composed of epithelial and stromal tissue; usually small, mobile, and common in younger women.
  • Duct ectasia (Option C): Benign dilation of subareolar milk ducts; may cause nipple discharge, inflammation, or nipple changes.
  • Fibroadenosis (Option D): Also called fibrocystic changes; characterised by lumpy, tender breasts often related to menstrual cycle hormonal fluctuations.

questions.text: Which among the following is the disorder of the involution phase according to the ANDI classification of benign breast diseases?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Duct ectasia is classified as a disorder of the involution phase in the ANDI (Association of Breast Surgery - Benign Breast Disease Classification).

Pathophysiology:

  • It involves dilatation of the subareolar milk ducts, typically in perimenopausal or postmenopausal women.
  • The duct walls thicken, and secretions can stagnate, causing inflammation and sometimes periductal fibrosis.

Clinical Features:

  • Nipple discharge (often sticky, thick, or greenish)
  • Periareolar mass or tenderness
  • Occasionally, nipple retraction or inversion

Investigations:

  • Ultrasound: Dilated ducts with debris
  • Mammography: May show ductal dilatation or microcalcifications
  • Ductography / Galactography: Can evaluate the ductal system for obstruction or papillomas

Management:

  • Conservative: Observation of asymptomatic
  • Medical: Anti-inflammatory drugs or antibiotics if infection is present
  • Surgical: Microdochectomy or major duct excision if symptomatic or for recurrent discharge

Explanation of other options:

Fibroadenoma (Option A): Disorder of the proliferative phase, arising from lobular hyperplasia; benign solid mass in younger women.
Nipple inversion (Option C): Usually a developmental anomaly rather than a disorder of the involution phase.
